flow.context: Gregory Scott Davis — Association Manager at Retreatia, Steamboat Springs. Retreatia manages ~250 vacation rentals (77% condos) plus HOA/association management, running on TRACK PMS with a dedicated inspection team separate from cleaning. They're actively hiring housekeeping supervisors and owner liaisons — QA capacity is clearly a pressure point. Gregory manages the condo association side, so he's either refereeing owner-vs-rental-ops damage disputes himself or can point you straight to whoever owns turnover inspections (likely Viktorija Hristovska, GM, or Dan Douglas, Director of Association Management). No shared schools or connections with Sam — lead with the ski-market angle (Sam just skied Jackson Hole in January).

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER
gatekeeper.say: Hey, could you get me through to Gregory? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Don't pitch. Don't explain. Dose info bit by bit. Sound like you belong on the line.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah, I work with a few other property managers in the Steamboat area on their inspection workflows. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no pitch. Just enough context to sound relevant. End with a redirect — you ask the questions.

branches.label: Can you tell me more? / He's busy
He's not available / take a message

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally — we help a couple other vacation rental companies with their turnover inspection process. I sent him a note already — would you mind giving him a heads up that I called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Plant the seed and move on. Don't argue with a gatekeeper. If blocked, exit clean.

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — UNAVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries at all. When's usually a good time to catch him? I'll try back then.
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get a callback window. Be friendly. Don't leave a pitch as a voicemail.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Gregory — I work with a few property managers in ski markets, actually just got back from Jackson Hole myself. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. The Jackson Hole mention signals you're a skier in the same mountain-resort world — not a random telemarketer. Don't rush. Let the question land.

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your kind of role. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but great. Let them talk. Whatever they say, bridge into pain or discovery.

heard_no.label: HEARD NO
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Laugh it off naturally. Immediately transition into the pain trigger. No dead air.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Don't fight it. Get a specific callback window. If they give one, that's a micro-commitment.

branches.label: Sure, try me later / gives a time

bad_timing_lock.label: LOCK CALLBACK
bad_timing_lock.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Really appreciate it, Gregory.
bad_timing_lock.note: Repeat the time back. Put it in your calendar immediately. This is a warm callback now.

confused_cold.label: COLD / SKEPTICAL RESPONSE
confused_cold.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll own that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it doesn't click?
confused_cold.note: Disarm with honesty. Asking for 30 seconds gives them control, which lowers resistance.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This split question re-opens the conversation about 40% of the time. The 'so nobody bugs you again' line makes them feel safe answering honestly.

bad_timing_lock_fallback.label: LOCK CALLBACK — FALLBACK
bad_timing_lock_fallback.say: Totally fair — when's a better window? I'll make sure it's quick.
bad_timing_lock_fallback.note: They said it's timing, not interest. Get a specific time and call back warm.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: Yeah so the reason I'm reaching out — I work with another association manager who runs a pretty similar condo-heavy operation in a ski market. They were dealing with this thing where the rental team would flip a unit, mark the inspection all good, and then two weeks later an owner calls saying there's a gouge in the hardwood or a cushion is stained — and nobody can prove when it happened. The association side gets stuck in the middle refereeing these damage disputes with no real documentation to point to. We built an AI tool that actually analyzes the turnover photos teams are already capturing — catches damage, missing items, changes to the unit — so there's a clear visual record after every single stay. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after 'every single stay.' Let the silence work. The pain is framed from HIS seat — association manager stuck refereeing between owners and rental ops with no proof. The specifics (gouge in hardwood, stained cushion) make it visceral.

branches.label: Tell me more / That's interesting / We do deal with that
That's not really my area / I handle the HOA side
We already have inspectors for that

warm_engaged.label: WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_engaged.say: Oh cool — so you deal with that owner-damage back-and-forth on the association side then?
warm_engaged.note: STOP selling. Start asking. Let him describe his world. Every answer gives you ammo for the close or tells you who to ask for.

branches.label: Sort of, but it's more someone else's area

discovery_association.label: DISCOVERY — HIS WORLD
discovery_association.say: That makes sense. So when something comes up — like an owner flags damage or a maintenance issue after a guest stay — how does that typically flow to you? Do owners come straight to the association side, or does the rental ops team loop you in?
discovery_association.note: Map his workflow. You're looking for: (1) does he see turnover photos, (2) who does he escalate to, (3) what frustrates him. His answers tell you whether to close him directly or ask for a referral.

branches.label: Describes his involvement and pain points
It goes to someone on the rental side
We have a process but it's not great

connects_to_ops.label: VALUE FROM HIS SEAT
connects_to_ops.say: Got it — so if there were a way to have an automatic visual record after every turnover that your association team could pull up when an owner calls about damage, that'd actually save you some of those back-and-forth headaches?
connects_to_ops.note: Bridge his pain to RapidEye's value without re-pitching features. If he agrees, move to booking. If he deflects to ops side, pivot to referral gracefully.

branches.label: Yeah that would help / sounds useful
That'd be more useful for the ops team / Viktorija / someone else
Maybe, but I'm not the one to evaluate tools
What does it cost / how does it work?

not_my_area.label: NOT MY AREA
not_my_area.say: That totally makes sense — you're more on the building and association side. Who on the rental ops or housekeeping side typically owns the inspection process? I know you guys run a separate inspection team from cleaning, which is pretty rare.
not_my_area.note: Show you know Retreatia's structure. The 'separate inspection team' detail proves you did homework and earns credibility. Listen for names — Viktorija (GM), Dan Douglas (Director of Association Mgmt), or a housekeeping lead.

branches.label: Not sure / I don't know who handles that

referral_bridge.label: BRIDGE TO REFERRAL
referral_bridge.say: Totally get it — sounds like this would land better with whoever runs the turnover and inspection workflow on the rental side. Who would that be on your team? I know Retreatia runs housekeeping and inspections pretty separately from each other.
referral_bridge.note: You're not asking him to buy. You're asking him to point you in the right direction. Lower pressure means higher compliance. Use what you know about Retreatia's structure to sound informed.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — GET THE NAME
referral_ask.say: Perfect — and what's their name? If I can put something tailored together it'll actually land instead of being another cold email that gets deleted.
referral_ask.note: Get first AND last name. If they give title only, ask 'And who's in that role right now?' Don't leave without a name.

branches.label: Won't share / just call the main line

referral_ask_viktorija.label: REFERRAL — VIKTORIJA
referral_ask_viktorija.say: Viktorija — got it. Is she pretty hands-on with the inspection and housekeeping side, or is there someone under her who runs that day-to-day?
referral_ask_viktorija.note: You already know Viktorija Hristovska is the GM and BBB principal contact. Confirm she's right AND fish for another name below her who might be more operational.

branches.label: She handles it / she's the one
There's someone else under her who runs it

referral_nudge.label: REFERRAL — NUDGE
referral_nudge.say: No worries — would it be someone like a Director of Operations or a Housekeeping Manager? I just want to make sure I'm reaching out to the right person so nobody wastes their time.
referral_nudge.note: Feed titles that exist at Retreatia. Dan Douglas is Director of Association Management — might be Gregory's boss. There may be ops or housekeeping leads you haven't found. Help him connect the dots.

referral_got_name.label: REFERRAL — LOCKED
referral_got_name.say: Really appreciate that, Gregory. I'll reach out to them directly. Would it be cool if I mentioned you pointed me their way? That way it doesn't feel like a random cold call for them either.
referral_got_name.note: Using his name as a warm intro is gold. If he says yes, your next call opens with 'Gregory on your association team suggested I reach out.' That changes everything.

branches.label: I'd rather you didn't / just reach out on your own

referral_offer_forward.label: REFERRAL — OFFER TO FORWARD
referral_offer_forward.say: Totally fair. Would it be easier if I sent you a quick one-pager and you just forwarded it to whoever makes sense? That way it comes from you and actually gets opened.
referral_offer_forward.note: If he won't give a name, give him something to forward. Low effort for him, warm intro for you.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should have assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would have reached out yourself.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Disarm completely. Then split the objection to find the real reason.

agree_split_interest.label: SPLIT — NOT INTERESTED
agree_split_interest.say: Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that property inspections aren't really something you think about in your role, or is it more that you've just got a million things going on right now?
agree_split_interest.note: You're fishing for: 'not my area' leads to referral path, 'bad timing' leads to callback. Either answer re-opens the conversation.

branches.label: Not my area / not my role

objection_have_inspectors.label: OBJECTION — HAVE INSPECTORS
objection_have_inspectors.say: That makes total sense — with 250-plus units you'd have to have a dedicated team. Retreatia's actually known for running inspections separate from cleaning, which is pretty rare in this market.
objection_have_inspectors.note: Compliment their process. Reference specific details you know (separate inspection team, 250 units). Show respect, then split.

agree_split_inspectors.label: SPLIT — HAVE INSPECTORS
agree_split_inspectors.say: Just curious — is it that the inspection team catches everything and you're totally happy with the output, or is it more that you've got a system that works and switching anything right now would just be a headache?
agree_split_inspectors.note: Almost nobody says their process catches everything. The second option is safer to admit. Either way you learn something useful.

branches.label: We have gaps / it's not perfect
Not my call / I don't manage that

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone bring something new in.
objection_no_budget.note: Validate. Don't flinch. Then split to understand the real blocker.

agree_split_budget.label: SPLIT — NO BUDGET
agree_split_budget.say: Just so I know — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything you try to buy has to go through a pretty long approval process?
agree_split_budget.note: If budget is locked, plant a seed for later. If approval is the issue, offer the test drive to help build the case internally.

test_drive.label: TEST DRIVE — SELL THE LOOK
test_drive.say: You're probably not looking to buy anything right now and I totally respect that. But when budget does free up — or when peak season hits and things get crazy — the people who are ready are the ones who already know what's on their list. If nothing else, I could walk you through what other property managers in ski markets are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
test_drive.note: Remove all buying pressure. Make the meeting valuable even if they never purchase. 'Steal some ideas' is the safety net that gets people to say yes.

branches.label: Sure / I'd take a look at that
That'd be better for someone else on our team

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it doesn't just sit in your inbox like every other vendor email?
send_email.note: This question does two things: (1) makes your email actually useful, and (2) re-engages them in conversation. Listen carefully — their answer tells you what they actually care about.

branches.label: Tells you what they care about
Send it to someone else instead

email_close.label: CLOSE — EMAIL
email_close.say: Got it — I'll keep it tight and send that over today. I'll include a couple time options in case you want to dig into it after reading. What email's best for you — is it d-gregory at retreatia dot com?
email_close.note: Confirm email address. The 'couple time options' plants a meeting seed. Using the inferred email pattern sounds like you already have it — reduces friction.

branches.label: Actually let's just set up a time now

book_meeting.label: BOOK MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome — let me grab a time while I've got you. I'm looking at next Tuesday and Thursday. What works better on your end?
book_meeting.note: Give two options, not an open question. If neither works, let him counter. Don't lose momentum here.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you
I need to loop someone else in on this

lock_time.label: LOCK TIME
lock_time.say: Perfect — how's the afternoon look, like 2 o'clock your time?
lock_time.note: Narrow to the hour. Get the commitment locked and confirmed before hanging up.

lock_time_push.label: LOCK TIME — PUSH GENTLY
lock_time_push.say: Totally — tell you what, how about I throw a placeholder on for Thursday at 2? If something comes up we can always move it. That way it doesn't fall through the cracks.
lock_time_push.note: Don't let 'I'll get back to you' become a dead end. A placeholder commitment is better than nothing.

lock_time_plus_referral.label: LOOP SOMEONE IN
lock_time_plus_referral.say: Love that — who would you want on the call? I'll send the invite to both of you so it's easy.
lock_time_plus_referral.note: This is gold. He's bringing the right person to you. Get the name AND email for the invite.

branches.label: Let me figure that out and get back to you

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_booked.say: Locked in. I'll send the invite right now so it's on your calendar. Really appreciate you taking my call, Gregory — talk soon.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Confirm and get off the phone. Send the calendar invite within 60 seconds of hanging up. Include a one-line agenda so they remember what it's about.

end_referral_success.label: END — REFERRAL LOCKED
end_referral_success.say: Really appreciate the help, Gregory. I'll reach out to them and keep it relevant. If you ever want to see what we're doing on the property condition side, you know where to find me. Have a good one.
end_referral_success.note: Leave the door open for him too. He may circle back once the ops team shows interest. Send him a quick thank-you email within the hour.

end_with_email.label: END — EMAIL FOLLOW-UP
end_with_email.say: Perfect — I'll get that over to you today. Appreciate your time, Gregory. Talk soon.
end_with_email.note: Send the email within 30 minutes. Include: one-paragraph pain recap tailored to association management, a one-pager or short link, and two specific meeting time options. Subject line should reference Steamboat or Retreatia, not RapidEye.

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks at RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Gregory.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn bridges. He talks to the GM, the ops team, the owners. A respectful exit today can become a warm referral next month.
